<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2 (P2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 77, 153, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 308, 112]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int \frac{2}{4x - 1}\mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 918, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 133, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 123, 863, 170]]<|/det|>
Hence find \(\int_{1}^{7}\frac{2}{4x - 1}\mathrm{d}x,\) expressing your answer in the form \(\ln a\), where \(a\) is an integer. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 207, 97, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 838, 235]]<|/det|>
The curve \(y = \frac{\mathrm{e}^{3x - 1}}{2x}\) has one stationary point. Find the coordinates of this stationary point. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 262, 97, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 260, 918, 282]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(2\cot^{2}\theta -5\cos \mathrm{e}\theta = 10\), giving all solutions in the interval \(0^{\circ}\leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 310, 97, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 310, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
(i) The polynomial \(a x^{3} + b x^{2} - 25 x - 6\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \((x - 3)\) and \((x + 2)\) are factors of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 355, 148, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 355, 630, 375]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) and \(b\) have these values, factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 356, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 402, 96, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 401, 440, 421]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 428, 591, 448]]<|/det|>
\[x = 1 + \sqrt{t},\quad y = 3\ln t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 465, 153, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 465, 757, 485]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the gradient of the curve at the point \(P\) where \(y = 6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 466, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 496, 148, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 496, 724, 515]]<|/det|>
Show that the tangent to the curve at \(P\) passes through the point (1, 0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 497, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 549, 101, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 146, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 543, 361, 571]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int (\sin x - \cos x)^{2}\mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 549, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 144, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 586, 193, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 585, 702, 605]]<|/det|>
Use the trapezium rule with 2 intervals to estimate the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 612, 559, 650]]<|/det|>
\[\int_{\frac{1}{4}\pi}^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}\mathrm{cos}\mathrm{e}x\mathrm{~d}x,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 660, 576, 680]]<|/det|>
giving your answer correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 661, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 688, 193, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 687, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
Using a sketch of the graph of \(y = \cos \mathrm{e}x\) for \(0< x\leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\), explain whether the trapezium rule gives an under-estimate or an over-estimate of the true value of the integral in part (i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 719, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 82, 628, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 920, 298]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = 8x + \frac{1}{2}\mathrm{e}^{x}\). The shaded region \(R\) is bounded by the curve and by the lines \(x = 0\), \(y = 0\) and \(x = a\), where \(a\) is positive. The area of \(R\) is equal to \(\frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 310, 156, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 308, 839, 329]]<|/det|>
Find an equation satisfied by \(a\), and show that the equation can be written in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 333, 566, 369]]<|/det|>
\[a = \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 - \mathrm{e}^{a}}{8}\right)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 343, 917, 362]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 394, 153, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 388, 843, 425]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that the equation \(a = \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 - \mathrm{e}^{a}}{8}\right)}\) has a root between 0.2 and 0.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 395, 917, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 151, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 432, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula \(a_{n + 1} = \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 - \mathrm{e}^{a_n}}{8}\right)}\) to determine this root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 470, 917, 488]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
